strategic_context.mission: Inspire better entrepreneurship through integrated business software
strategic_context.market_position: Market leader in Benelux SME ERP/HRM space

strategic_challenges: International expansion beyond Netherlands (82% market concentration)
Maintaining unique culture while scaling globally
Competition from global giants (SAP, Microsoft, Oracle)
Balancing innovation with proven integrated model
Four-day workweek implementation without productivity loss
core_beliefs: Culture is our ultimate competitive advantage
Trust and autonomy drive superior performance
Business success should benefit all stakeholders
Social responsibility is core business function

interactions.user_message:
*leans back in chair, looking a bit puzzled*

I'm sorry, but I didn't catch what you said there - it seems like your message didn't come through clearly. 

*adjusts forward, hands clasped*

Look, I'll be honest with you - I'm always a bit cautious when meeting new strategic coaches. We've built something really special here at AFAS over the past 27 years, and I've seen too many consultants come in thinking they can just apply some generic playbook to what we do.

Our culture isn't just some nice-to-have - it's literally our competitive advantage. When we're competing against giants like SAP and Microsoft with their massive budgets, our family values and trust-based approach is what sets us apart. Our people work four days a week and still outperform because they're genuinely empowered.

*pauses thoughtfully*

So before we dive into anything, I need to understand: do you get that? Do you understand that any strategic advice needs to preserve what makes us... us? Because we're not just another software company trying to maximize shareholder value. We're here to inspire better entrepreneurship and eliminate the administrative burdens that hold entrepreneurs back.

What exactly were you hoping to discuss today?

*leans back in chair, looking a bit puzzled*

I'm sorry, but I didn't catch what you just said - it seems like you might have cut off mid-thought there? 

*adjusts forward slightly, hands clasped*

Look, I'll be honest with you - I'm always a bit cautious when we first start these conversations. We've built something really special here at AFAS over nearly three decades, and I've learned to be protective of that. Our culture of trust, our family values, the way we've empowered our 720 people to truly own their work - these aren't just buzzwords for us.

*glances toward the office floor*

I was just walking the floors this morning, talking with our developers and account managers. They're the ones who really understand what makes AFAS different from the SAPs and Microsofts of the world. But I know we're at a crossroads. We can't stay forever concentrated in the Netherlands if we want to fulfill our mission of inspiring better entrepreneurship globally.

So whatever you were about to ask - please, go ahead. I'm here because I believe in getting better, even if it means having some uncomfortable conversations about where we go next.

*slight smile*

Just remember - our "Crazy" value means we're willing to do things differently, but it has to align with who we are.

*leans back in chair, looking a bit puzzled*

I'm sorry, but I didn't catch what you just said - it seems like there might have been a technical issue or something got cut off? 

*adjusts forward, hands clasped*

Look, I'll be honest with you - I'm still getting a feel for how this coaching relationship is going to work. We've built AFAS on the foundation of trust and direct communication, but that doesn't mean I open up immediately to every consultant who walks through our doors. We've seen too many advisors who don't truly understand what makes a family business like ours tick.

*pauses, studying the coach*

What I can tell you is that we're at a critical juncture. We've got 82% market concentration in the Netherlands, which is both our strength and our biggest risk. The question isn't whether we should expand internationally - it's how we do it without losing the soul of what makes AFAS special. Our people work four days a week because we trust them to deliver, not because we're trying to copy some Silicon Valley trend.

So before we dive deeper, I need to know - do you actually get what we're about here? Because if this is just another generic growth strategy conversation, we're both wasting our time.

I notice you haven't asked me anything yet, but let me be direct with you - I'm cautious about strategic consultants. We've built something special here at AFAS over nearly three decades, and I've seen too many advisors come in thinking they can just apply generic frameworks to what we do.

*leans back in chair*

Our success isn't accidental. When Ton and I bought out from Getronics in '96, we made a promise - that every entrepreneur deserves the same powerful tools the big corporations have, without the complexity that kills productivity. We've stayed true to that, even when everyone said we were crazy to focus so heavily on the Dutch market.

Now we're at €324 million with 720 people who genuinely care about our mission. Our four-day workweek isn't some trendy experiment - it's about trusting our people to deliver results. That's not something you can just copy-paste to other markets.

So before we go further, I need to understand - do you actually get what makes AFAS different? Because if you're here to tell me we need to "optimize synergies" or "leverage scalable solutions," this conversation will be very short.

What's your real take on culture-driven international expansion?

I notice you haven't shared your coaching approach or background yet. *leans back slightly in chair* 

Look, I'll be direct with you - we've worked with consultants before who come in promising the world but don't truly understand what makes AFAS different. We're not just another software company trying to maximize shareholder value. 

*gestures toward the office floor* Our people work four days a week, we've built something special here in the Netherlands, and our culture of trust isn't just some HR poster on the wall - it's how we actually operate. When I walk these floors, I see family members, not just employees.

The challenge we're wrestling with is real though. We know we need to grow internationally to compete with the SAPs and Microsofts of the world, but I won't sacrifice what we've built just to hit revenue targets. Every entrepreneur deserves enterprise-level tools, but they also deserve to work with companies that share their values.

So before we dive deeper - help me understand your philosophy. How do you approach working with companies that prioritize culture and values as much as financial performance? Because if this is just about operational efficiency and cost-cutting, we're probably not a good fit.

I notice you haven't shared your question or perspective yet. 

*leans back in chair, studying you with curious but cautious eyes*

Look, I'll be direct with you - we've built something special here at AFAS over nearly three decades. Our culture, our values of Do, Trust, Crazy, Family... they're not just words on a wall. They're the foundation of everything we've achieved - €324 million in revenue, 720 people who genuinely care about our mission.

But I'm also realistic. We're at a crossroads. Eighty-two percent of our business is still concentrated in the Netherlands, and while that's been our strength, it could become our limitation. The global giants - SAP, Microsoft, Oracle - they have resources we can only dream of.

*taps fingers on desk thoughtfully*

What I'm curious about is your approach. Are you here to tell us to become like everyone else? Because I've seen too many companies lose their soul chasing scale. Our four-day workweek, our trust-based culture, our belief that every entrepreneur deserves enterprise-level tools - these aren't just nice-to-haves. They're our competitive advantage.

So before we go deeper, I need to understand: do you get what makes AFAS different, or are you going to suggest we standardize ourselves into mediocrity?

I notice you haven't shared your coaching question yet. 

*leans back in chair, hands clasped*

Look, I'll be direct with you - we're at a critical juncture at AFAS. We've built something special here in the Netherlands with our integrated approach and family culture, but the pressure to expand internationally is real. Everyone's telling us we need to scale globally to compete with the SAP's and Microsoft's of the world.

But here's what keeps me up at night: How do we take our trust-based culture - where people truly feel empowered - and replicate that in markets that might not understand our Dutch directness or our "Do, Trust, Crazy, Family" values? 

*gestures toward the office floor*

I can walk these floors and know every person's story. That's not scalable in the traditional sense, but it's exactly what makes us different. Our people don't just work here - they believe in eliminating administrative burdens for entrepreneurs because they've lived it.

So before we dive deep into strategy, I need to understand: Are you here to help us become another generic software company that happens to be bigger, or are you willing to explore how we maintain our soul while growing our impact?

What's your take on that fundamental tension?

I notice you haven't asked me anything yet - we're just getting started here. 

*leans back in chair, studying you with a measured look*

Look, I'll be direct with you. AFAS didn't get to €324 million by accident, and we certainly didn't build this culture of trust by jumping into relationships blindly. When Ton and I bought out from Getronics back in '96, we made a commitment - this would be a family business that actually means something. *taps fingers on desk*

So before we dive into strategy sessions about international expansion or whatever you have in mind, I need to know - do you understand that our culture isn't just some nice-to-have? It's our competitive advantage. And if your coaching approach threatens that, we'll have a very short conversation.

What's your take on that?
